almes thinges within beholde thing shalbe cleane vnto heere sette downe agreeth parte wholely wyth doctrine fiftene chapter mat christ purpose neglected outwarde rite inuented men obseruing whereof iewes carefull hee might correcte superstition people especially scribe god commaunded certaine washing lawe whiche hee profitably exercised people meditation true puritie iewes content thys mediocritie added many washinges specially man shoulde eat except washed mark declareth plainly 7 chapter also appeareth 2 iohn also fault added wicked confidence hauing regard spirituall worship god thought wel discharged themselues set vp figure place god christe ignorant contempt ceremony woulde offensiuely taken yet omitted might shewe god made small account outwarde cleannesse flesh required spirituall righteousnes hart 3 • deede yee pharisies christe doeth reproue pharisies place doth mathew mark preposterously worshipped god men inuentions brake lawe god owne tradition onlye toucheth grosse hypocrisie desired puritie eye men nothing god reproofe lighteth vpon hypocrite establish righteousnesse ceremony commanded god therfore christe concludeth shoulde haue sayde god worshipped vaine commandements men generally condemneth errour god shoulde worshipped ceremony faith pure affection heart though prophet alwayes hadde great controuersie matter wyth iewes yet disposition men prone hypocrisie proud errour preuailed god pleased outward worshippings voide faith chiefly astonied christes time religion stode mere trifle therefore enueyeth pharisies busily occupied washing cuppes nourish inwardly hart filthy spot rauening wickednes cōdemneth folly reason god created inward soule man well body could pleased outward shew chiefly deceiueth men either doe consider haue doe god else transforme according vanitie imagination differed nothing mortall man 41 thinges within christ maner calleth pharisies backe ceremony charitie affirming men wel meat clēsed water loue yet wold woords lessen grace god reiecte rite lawe vaine vnprofitable directeth speach carelesly mocke god naked signes haue sayd onely lawfull vse sanctifieth meates onely doe vse meates rightly iustly helpe want poore aboundance therefore better giue almes abundance haue scrupulous washing hand cuppes neglect poore papist doe gather heereof almes satisfaction purged sinnes fonde needeth long confutation christ disputeth heere price behooueth v obtaine forgiuenesse sinnes doe eate bread rightly bestow part vpon poore take greke word vsed signifieth presently old interpreater erasmus translate remaineth best reserue reprofes doe presently folow place doe thinke christe presently table enuey scribe pharisies luke se downe spoken time haue often sayde euangelists regarded order time mathewe marke luke 14 1 came passe entred house one chiefe pharisies sabboth day eate bread watched 2 beholde certaine manne dropsie 3 iesus answearinge spake vnto expounder lawe pharisies saying lawfull heale sabboth day 4 helde peace tooke healed let goe 5 answeared saying shall haue asse oxe falne pit wil straight way pull cut sabboth day 6 could answer thing hystorie containeth nothing else myracle wrought christ whereby reproued superstitious obseruation sabboth neither purpose imagine simply abrogate sabboth shew neither worke god dueties charity violate holy rest commanded law also vncertaine whether man dropsie purposely brought thither appoyntment certainly could come table aduenture enter priuate house without leaue lord vvherefore likely brought thither craftely tempt christe yet lesse foolishly wickedly done experience christ accustomed doe oft like occasion offered 5 lawfull heale sabboth day meaning question whether healing man ought accounted amongst workes doe breake sabboth haue sayd obseruation sabboth shoulde broken meanes exception ready worke god law sabboth containeth nothing else men shoulde rest owne labour christ first asketh question might therby preuent offence therfore cause pleased obstinate malice hee alwayes bounde condition oft time regarding offence performed whiche enioyned father wil teache example wrought myracles sabboth dayes rashly ready giue accoūt declare silēce rather take occasion reprehēd moued study law therfore christ hath regarde iudge euident would willingly take occasion offence 5 vvhich shall haue asse though vnwoorthy christe endeuour mitigate displeasure yet hee declareth hath done nothing obseruation sabboth doeth muche purpose teach might thereby deliuer himselfe slaunders knew shewed themselues rather bee blinded poysonfull hatred yeelde themselues taughte reason triumphe ouer malice enforced shame hold peace lawfull helpe brute beastes sabboth day vile thing duety man framed made image god mathewe marke luke 14 7 hee spake also parable guestes hee marked howe chose oute chiefe roumes sayde vnto 8 vvhen thou shalt bidden man wedding set thy self downe chiefest place least honourable man thou bidden 9 hee badde thee come say thee giue man roume thou begin shame take lowest roume 10 thou art bidden goe sitte downe lowest roume hee badde thee commeth may say vnto thee friend sitte vp hier shalt thou haue woorship presence sitte table thee 11 soeuer exalteth himselfe shalbe brought lowe hee humbleth himselfe shalbe exalted 12 sayde also bidden thou makest dinner supper call thy frendes thy brother neither thy kinsman rich neighbour least also bidde thee againe recompence made thee 13 thou makest feast call poore maimed lame blinde 14 thou shalt blessed recompence thee thou shalt recompenced resurrection iust 7 spake guestes vve know greatly ambition raigned pharisies scribe proudly desired raigne ouer men also contention mutually amongst themselues chiefest men desirous vaine glory haue thys affection euery one doeth enuie eache euery one desireth drawe himselfe whiche others thinke due pharisies scribe chalenge people giue vnto title holy order striue amongst themselues degree honour euery chalenge himselfe chiefe place christ aptly derideth ambition fitte similitude man occupy chiefe roume mannes table enforced giue place better hee shall sette lower master feast without shame ignominie necessary shoulde befall proudly lift vppe selues rule ouer others god shall cast downe shame noted christ preacheth heere outwarde ciuill modestie see proudest menne oft time excell behalfe ciuilitie say pretende greatest modestie similitude taken vse men teacheth v inwardly god say befal vnto guest foolishly chose highest roume thrust downe lowest shame hee desire neuer climed thither therefore least god put thing practise amongst arrogantie stained extreme ignominic willingly submit selues humilitie modestie 11 vvho soeuer exalteth selfe clause declareth christ spake ambition sheweth vseth befall common life menne heere maketh god iudge resisteth proud pulleth downe proude lookes giueth grace humble scripture full suche place god wil enemie al whiche desire lifte vppe themselues necessity must haue battell god doe arrogate thing themselues pride glory giftes god worthinesse v owne deseruing extoll v againe fained casting downe ought accounted humility true humbling whē rightly acknowledging selues owne infirmity lifting vp selues knowing excell onely grace god 12 vvhen thou makest dinner thinke feastes heere simply condemned whiche kinsfolkes friendes doe make amongst selues doe take away part humanity amongst menne rather barbarous austere shutte thy kinsfolkes thy table onely giue place straungers neither purpose christe driue v neighbourhoode onely shew charitie litle vsed ordinary dealing world liberality bestowe thinge vppon riche menne hope gaine whome hope receiue like kinde vsurie woorkes rewarde accounted god woorthy name charitie bidde kinsfolkes rich friendes supper humanitie selfe condemned smally auaileth prooue charitie oft time see whiche wholey addicted themselues bestowe great charge receiuinge friendes delicately vvhat thou mayest furnish thy table riche menne meane season thou neglectest poore lawfull feast thy friendes kinsfolkes thou reiectest straungers poore thou hast habilitie helpe neede summe liberall kinsfolkes friendes harde poore worthy praise exercise charitie prouide onely owne gaine ambition christ speaketh hoast name whome sawe giuen muche sumptuousnesse dainty gette praise fauour riche men smally regarded poore vnder person one man reproued ambitiously spende thing • haue either owne glory gette like recompence yet bestow nothing vppon poore afraid soeuer bestowed freely lost therfore christe sayeth blessed liberall without hope earthly rewarde euident haue regarde god cause sette regarde profite eye desire praise people shoulde looke rewarde god mathewe 22 marke luke 14 1 iesus answeared spake vnto parable saying 2 kingdō heauen like vnto certaine king maried son 3 sent foorth seruaunts call bidden wedding would come 4 sent forth seruāts saying tel thē biddē behold haue prepared dinner mine ox fatlings killed thing ready come vnto mariage 5 made light went wayes one farme another marchandise 6 • nant tooke seruaunts intreated sharply slewe 7 king heard wroth sent forth warriours destroied murtherers burnt vp citie 8 said seruants truely wedding prepared bidden worthy 9 go ye therefore high wayes many yee finde bidde mariage 10 seruaunts went high wayes gathered togither euer founde good badde weddinge furnished guestes 11 king came see guest saw man wedding garment 12 saide vnto friend camest thou hither hast weddinge garment hee speachlesse 13 said king seruāts binde hand foote take away cast vtter darkenes shalbe weeping gnashing teethe 14 many called fewe chosen 15 one sate table heard thing said vnto haue bought farme must go see pray thee haue excused 19 another sayde haue bought fiue yeake ox got pr • oue praythe • haue excused 20 another sayde haue maried wife therefore come 21 seruaunt odious sermon set downe also brought course neglecting order time hystorie set downe luke noted one guest saide blessed eat bread kingdom god christ toke occasion therby reproue vnthankfulnesse iewes cuppes eternal life thinke man cast speache blessednesse come againe might gather somewhat christe woordes doe declare yet sauoured nothing grosse earthly vseth phrase eate bread metaphorically enioying eternall glory seemeth dreame knowe state replenished prosperous abundance thing yet meaning happy eate breade god hath gathered child kingdome 2 kingdome heauen like spartane sayd time past athenian knew thing right would christ heere reproueth iewes coulde speake many notable word kingdom god god calleth louingly gently vnto contemptuously refuse grace douted pincheth iewes name shall haue noted also like difference mathewe hath bene plentifull large entreating matter summe agree well god vouchsafed peculiar honour iewes preparing banketting boarde despised honour offered many interpreaters doe apply mariage king sonne christ end lawe god regarde purpose couenāt might sette ouer people might ioyne church holy bande spirituall mariage doe willingly embrace allowe sayeth seruaunts sent call bidden woordes noteth double grace god witte preferred iewes nation reuealed vnto adoption prophet alludeth vsuall maner men making mariage feastes doe wryte downe catalogue whome woulde haue guestes bid seruaunts god chose iewes others though shoulde familiar friendes calleth hy • prophet might pertakers promised redēption feasted mariage though first called liued vnto comming christ yet knowe saluation proposed common wherof depriued vnthankefulnesse malice people wickedly despised calling god beginning 4 againe hee sent foorth others hee speaketh menne one body people meaning happie ioyfull day redemption drewe neare warned might ready time time appoynted long nowe christ sayeth called poynte time might haste come first callinge whereof maketh mention comprehendeth al former prophesies preaching gospell though people raged prophet yet accuseth olde people onely pride contempt fury encreased time whiche length powred violence vppon christe apostle sayeth seruaunts sent last euen supper time sharply entreated slaine outragious crueltye ioyned proude reiecting grace people brake extreemest sinnes yet layeth offence vpon togither last calling went farme another husbandrie luke reporteth one excused himselfe hadde maried wife boughte farme bought fiue yoake ox word christ declareth iewes giuen world earthly thing 〈◊〉 none thē leisure come god care world doe holde v bound many allurement withdraw v kingdome heauen vile shamefull matter men created heauenly life shuld beast caried transitory thinges disease spred euery one scarce hundred preferreth kingdome god vaine richesse commodity though haue disease yet euery one caryed owne couetousnesse contrary course commeth passe men run order hither thither furthermore noted prophane men make shewe honest pretence refusinge grace god though slouthe excused applying themselues affaire present life doe little esteeme heauenly enheritāce see christ might draw v suche delites teacheth manne thinke himselfe hath profited thing entāgle themselues earthly hinderāces nay fault men doubled hinder themselues thing otherwise lawfull ought rather holpen ende doth god graunt v commodity present life might allure v vnto euery man farre holpe benefit god aspire heauen holy mariages field richesse many snare doe holde men bound earth 7 king heard mathew onely maketh mention punishment luke woorde spoken iniurie done seruants say excluded depriued honour feast came time appoynted thys doctrine also common v destruction whiche christe pronoūceth iewes remaineth wicked one doe violently rise minister gospell whiche withdrawne earthly care regarde callinge god famished men shall length miserably waste away want therefore ofte calleth v lette v ready glad followe 9 goe yee therefore hie wayes hath shewed vnwoorthy grace god doe proudly refuse offered vnto nowe sayeth others shall placed roome euen base contemptible common people calling gentile described prouoke iewes treasure 12 yee haue beene faithfull man good giue somewhat 14 thing heard pharisies also whiche couetous mocked 15 sayd vnto yee iustifie selues menne god knoweth heart highly esteemed among men abhomination sight god summe parable deale louingly kindly neighbour whē shal come tribunal seat god frute liberality may return vpon v though similitude semeth hard far fetched yet end sheweth christ purpose hereby perceiue apply thēselues fondly parable scrupulously sift perticular poyntes christ cōmandeth liberal giftes redeme deceit theft prodigall spending offence euill stewardship god hath made v steward bestow goodes giueth vnto v heere meane prescribed v time counte day shal come shal ease extreme rigor imagin almes shal make recōpence luxurious dissolute life doe sufficiently consider first enioyned v shoulde liue soberly temperately water shuld flow vnto v pure fountain certain man thrifty shall sometime lose good laid vp therfore euen apply thē selues greatest sparing altogither fre euil bestowing adde also ther manifold abuse gift god commit offence way deny finde selues guilty euil bestowing shuld rather stirre v vp dueties charitie ought set end v shuld paying price redemption escape iudgement god wit liberality well holily bestowed bridle correct superfluous expences kindnesse towards brother might prouoke mercy god towardes v vvherfore lord doth heere shew disciple way escape whereby might deliuer themselues guiltinesse heauenly iudge shall aske account warneth take hede betime least bear punishment cruelty taken wastfully spoyling blessing god way applying good vse alwaies holden vvhat measure man meateth others shalbe measured againe math 7 2 8 lord commended also easie see shal fondly shall stande vppon eache perticular poynts sith giue mannes goodes nothing praise worthy would beare patient minde spoyled wicked varlet pleasure shoulde release dettes certeinely token grosse blockishnes man see part substance spoyled allow rest stolne giuen others onely purpose christ addeth presently men prophane giuē worlde wiser warier looking accountes transitorie lyfe child god careful heauenly eternal lyfe bent study meditation comparison vpbraideth v slouthfulnes beyond al reason least haue like care prouide come whiche prophane men haue prouiding themselues worlde vile thing child light god shyneth spirit word slow neglect hope eternal blessednes offred worldly men greedily caried cō modities prouident wise aboute heereby wee gather wisdome spirite fleshe compared togeather could without reproofe god himselfe faithfull onely stirred vppe diligently consider thing apperteine life come shut eies light gospel see blynd men see better darke truely behooueth affected see child woorlde foresee longe life transitory passeth away moment 9 make friendes christe commaunded heretofore offer sacrifice god thinges stolne meaneth eyther excuser patrones sought hide defend v vnder defence teacheth bestowing louingly fauour god obtained promiseth hee likewise wil mercifull mercifull kinde fondlye absurdly doe reason doe gather holpen praiers suite dead whatsoeuer bestowed vpon vnworthy lost wickednes men hynder lord writeth vp table whatsoeuer bestow vpon poore therefore lorde hath regard person worke selfe louing kindnes shal answere v god yea though fall vppon vnthankfull men seemeth signifie eternal lyfe giuen recompence desert aunswere appeareth plainely enough text speaketh maner men wit exalted fauour rich get himselfe friendes prosperous estate hee hath falleth aduersitie shalbe sustayned kindnes shalbe v conueniēt refuge whatsoeuer man shal bestow liberaly vpon neighbour lord acknowledgeth bestowed vppon vvhen yee shall want word noteth time death hee warneth v time stewardshippe shal shorte whereof commeth passe greater parte sleepe rich many wast haue prodigall expense others hoardinge doe malitiously defraud themselues others beeing deceiued false imagination long lyfe doe flatter themselues securitie calleth rich iniquity hee might make v suspect rich part entangle theyr owner iniquitie though euill themselues yet seldome gotten without deceite violence vnlawfull meanes also rarely possessed kept without pride luxuriousnes wicked affection christ causeth v worthily suspect place also called thornes mat 13 22 yet seemeth vnderstoode opposition hee shoulde haue sayd rich otherwise defile owner wicked abuse almost snare sinnes must turned contrary end might get v fauour furthermore must bee remembred said god desireth sacrifice pray vniustly gotten companion theeues therfore rather admonition faithful preserue selues free iniquity 10 faythfull least prouerbial sentenses gathered common vse experience therefore sufficeth bee true parte shall befall somtimes deceiuer accounting smal gaine shal shew forth wickednes great matter yea many small matter vnder pretence simplicity hunt great gaine liuy sayth fraud getteth credit smal matter worthy labour may deceiue great reward yet notwithstanding saying christ false prouerbes sayd follow commonly vsed christ therefore exhorteth disciple dealing faithfully small matter might accustome themselues faithfull greatest matter thē applyeth doctrine right dispēsing spiritual grace though world esteeme according value yet certeine farre excell transitory rich world teacheth vnmeete god shoulde commit incomparable treasure gospell lyke giftes deale naughtily vnfaythfully matter lesse value fleeting rich world therefore included wordes secrete threatning feared least abuse earthlye stewardshyppe wee depriued heauenlye gyftes sense heauenlye blessednesse opposed rich perfecte perpetuall good thing shadowe transitorie matter 12 yee faithfull man goodes hee calleth mannes without manne god doth giue v rich condition tied vnto made v steward least holde v bound bandes cannot mindes free lybertie dwel heauen excepte account whatsoeuer world belonge others hee maketh spirituall rich belong lyfe come enioying eternall hee vseth similitude hoped wee vse owne goodes well moderately wee deale yll vnfaythfully men menne vse carelesly abuse theyr owne graunt themselues lybertie loosing afrayde manne shoulde reproue warye fearefull layde vppe committed lent thinges must account giuen againe therefore vnderstand meaning christe euyll keeper spirituall gyftes whiche doe dispose earthlye goodes euyll sentence sette downe manne serue god rich haue expounded sixt chapter matthe lette reader see word mamm • n signifieth 14 thinges heard pharises thinke pharises scorned christ taught common rude speach gloried swelling word sufficiently consider luke word graunt doctrine gospell seemeth contemptible proud disdainful men luke expresly declareth christ therefore scorned couetous throughly perswaded setled blessed whiche rich therfore better thing encrease substaunce meanes couetously hold gotten goodes whatsoeuer christ shuld say contrary reiected absurd paradox certēly whosoeuer speaketh dispising rich giuing poore seemeth couetous mean deceit saying horace wel known people hisseth reioyce self condēned iudgmēt al men yet please thē selues much shal scorne fable wisdō christ far minde common sort yet doubt pharises pretended colour might merilye iest doctrine sinne yet noted moued disease reigned almost alwayes world greater part men apply themselues scorne agreeth manner hereof commeth word god daunger many reproofes taunt furious scornes euery man striueth defence sinnes thinke iesting speaches cloud couer hide offēce 15 yee iustifie selues vve see christe giueth place pride constantly defendeth authoritie doctrine scornes minister gospell must also setting terrible iudgment god wicked contemners affirmeth coloured deceite wherewith deceiue eies men shal profit thing iudgment god would thought scornings defended couetousnes christ teacheth venom brake theyr hydden byle man say horned byshoppes day enemy gospell odious dealinges sharply pricked saieth think enough appeare honest men may set thēselues feigned holynes god searcher heart cannot hyde sinnes hyde world vvhere also noted difference iudgments god men men pleased outward shews nothing approued iudgment seat god sincere heart followeth anotable sentence whatsoeuer rightly esteemed amonge menne abhominatiō sight god god refuseth vertues whose praise hath imprinted heart menne god abhorreth whatsoeuer man extolleth iudgment whereby appeareth much faigned worshippings accounted world hath framed owne deuice though please inuenters christe saieth onelye vaine bee accounted beefore god also abhominable matth mark luke 16 19 certeine rich man clothed purple fine linen fared wel • delicately euery day 20 also certeine begger named lazarus layde gate ful sore 21 desired refreshed crou • e fell rich man table yea dog came licked sore 22 begger died caried angel abraham bosom rich man also dyed buryed 23 hell torment hee lyfte vp eye saw abraham far lazarus bosome 24 hee cryed sayde father abraham haue mercy send lazarus hee maye dippe typpe finger water coole tongue tormented flame 25 abraham sayde sonne remember thou thy life time receiuedst thy pleasure likewise lazarus paine therfore comforted thou art tormented 26 besides al betweene v great gulfe set woulde goe hence cannot neither come thence v 27 sayd pray thee therfore father th •• thou wouldest send father house 28 haue fiue brother hee may testifie vnto least also come vnto place torment 29 abraham said vnto haue moses prophet let heare 30 said nay father abraham one come dead would amend liues 31 said vnto heare moses prophet neither wil perswaded though one rise dead againe though luke hath set downe thinges betweene yet doubted confirmeth former sermon example sheweth portion remaineth hauing regard poore wholly waste themselues deintie delicates giuen surfettings pleasure suffer neighbor miserable hunger yea famish cruelly hauing abilitie ought helpe though seemeth simple parable yet name lazarus set downe rather thinke report matter done matter small importaunce reader doe holde summe doctrine first rich man brought cladde purple fine linen filling pleasaunt deinties euery day wordes noted delicate life filled pleasure pompes al finenes gorgeousnes apparel self displeaseth god delicacie meates damnable seldom falleth temperaunce kept thinges desireth gorgeousnes new garment shal prouocations encrease lust scarsly otherwise throw intemperancy delighteth deinties table delicately filled yet crueltie especially condemned suffered lazarus poore full sore lye without gate christe sette togeather contrary amongst themselues rich manne giuen belly cheere pompes gulfe filled shoulde deuoure within great heapes touched want misery lazarus wittingly willingly suffered starue hunger coulde stinch sore maner doth ezech 16 49 accuse sodom fulnesse bread wine stretched foorth hand poore well knowne inhabitantes easte woont vse fine lynen gorgeousnes pomp maner sacrificinge papistes counterfeted garmentes call surplus 21 dogges came hard yron crueltie rich man sufficiently condemned miserable spectacle could moue compassion bene droppe humanitie haue commaunded leaste fragmentes kitchen haue bene giuen man misery heape wicked beastly crueltie learne mercy dogges neither doubte dogges directed secrete counsel god condemne example christ alleadgeth testimonie reproue cursed hardnes man woonderfull dogges shoulde haue care man neglected neighbour nay • would giue crummes bread hungry man dog lent tongue helpe heale therefore oft either straungers bruit beastes doe take roumes doe rather haue done let v know many witness iudges appoynted god v shall discouer faulte 22 begger died christ declareth howe much estate hee hath yet remnaunt former pride behalfe see prophane menne stryuing sorte nature glory buryall funerall solemnityes desire haue shewes remayning theyr estate foolish ridiculous ambition soules hell feeling misery desire refreshing yet al hope taken away feele double torment yea tormented enforced remember sinnes compare present blessednes faithful owne miserable damnable estate purpose ende description talke shuld haue passed betweene thē haue felowship betweene themselues also rich man calleth abraham father expressed torment late feeleth reiected number child abraham 25 sonne remember name sonne seemeth set downe derision might sharpe reproofe pinch rich manne gloried falsly life one childrē abrahā mind wounded blow burning hot yron hypocrisie deceitfull trust obiected set eye said tormented hell receiued pleasure world may taken eternall destruction remayned al liue wel prosperously world nay augustine noted verye wisely poore lazarus therefore caryed bosome rich abraham myght know rich shut gate kingdome heauen manne generally open doe eyther vse theyr rich soberly doe beare theyr wantes patiently onely meaning hee beeing droonke enticementes lyfe drowned himselfe earthly delightes despised god kingdome suffereth punishmentes carelesse dealyng therefore pronoune thy verye forcible abraham haue sayde thou wert created immortall lyfe law god haue lyfte thee vp meditate heauenly lyfe thou forgetfull excellent lotte hadst rather lyke swine dog therefore thou receiuest iust reward thy brutish pleasure againe sayd lazarus receyued comfort bore many misery world shoulde fondly draw menne misery whiche haue receyued litle profit affliction shall rather ende extreame punishment bearing crosse praysed lazarus alwayes commeth faith sincere feare god hee obstinately refuseth euilles continueth one vntamed wildnesse deserueth prayse patience god shoulde recompence comfort affliction summe therefore tendeth purpose patientlye beare burden affliction layde vppon doe stubbornely striue yoke scourge god continuall trouble shall aspyre hope better lyfe quiet ioy layd vp heauen tyme theyr warfare expired side prophane despisers god gorge themselues pleasure flesh doe choake vppe study godlynesse certeine surfetinge minde tormentes prepared presentlye death whiche may shake away vaine delight remembred comfort child god enioy standeth beholding crowne glory prepared rest ioyful waiting feeling iudgement come see ready tormenteth wicked 26 besides wordes noted perpetuitie state lyfe come haue bene sayd bondes distinguishe reprobate elect neuer broken warned returne speedily way time least runne headlong deepe gulfe whence cannot ryse spoken vnproperly passage shut man would descend heauen hell certeine desire neuer commeth godly 27 pray thee therefore father might better apply hystory vse proposeth desire rich man yt lazarus might go warne brother yet alyue papist reason fondly would proue hence dead haue care liuing cauill deut 30 12 thou shalt say shall ascende heauen shall descend deepe shal passe ouer sea word neere vnto thee thy mouth thine hearte therefore doe deride fable thinges scripture testifieth iudgement come shall tyme come feele intollerable wickednesse discredite holy oracle god christe wakeneth slouthful disease least beeing deceiued hope escape punishment shoulde let escape time repentaunce tendeth abraham aunswere god sufficiently throughly delyuered people doctrine saluation moses prophetes wanteth thing else al men rest wisdome manne altogeather infected wicked disease curiositie greater part alwayes gapeth reuelations nothing displeaseth god thē men desirously wander beyond boundes seeke trueth magitians sothsayers seeke feigned oracle manner gentile forbydden staying ytching hee also promyseth giue vnto prophetes people shoulde learne whatsoeuer shoulde bee profitable theyr saluation deut 18 10 18 prophetes sente ende god myght keepe people vnder brydle worde testament added full interpretation gospell caried hither thither loathing doctrine briefly suffer selues ruled word impietie borne heereof may also gathered assurance purgatory tri • le papistes hath ground vpon dreames vision 30 nay father abraham prosopopaeia haue said rather sette downe vnderstanding liue care dead doctrine lawe waxeth colde worlde prophesies lye regarded man abydeth heare god speake owne order desire aungelles shoulde descend heauen others dead shoulde come theyr graues others would haue whatsoeuer heare sanctified newe myracles others would haue voyces speake ayre god yeelde theyr preposterous desire would profitte nothing thereby god setteth downe word▪ whatsoeuer profitable v knowe aucthority worde testified confirmed vnto v lawful signes fayth dependeth vppon myracles vppon sortes myracles peculyar gift spirte▪ grounded worde god conclude proper gyft god draw v vnto whose worke effectualy word vvherfore hope meanes shuld profit v draw v obedience word graunte flesh apter readyer thing hearken vaine reuclations see loath scripture earnestly throw themselues snare sathan heereof sprang necromacy like deceites worlde dooth onely receyue greedinesse also madde violence shee draweth vnto christ declareth deafe obstinate doctrine law cannot amended brought better mind dead matth mark luke 17 7 vvho also hauing seruaunt • plowing feeding cattell would say vnto come field goe sitte downe table 8 would rather say dresse wherwith may suppe girde thy selfe serue till haue eaten▪ dr • nke afterward eat th •• drinke thou 9 doth thanke seruaunt beecause hee commaunded vnto trow 10 lykewise yee yee haue done thinges commaunded say vnprofitable seruauntes haue done duetie ende parable god chalengeth haue himselfe owne proper right holdeth v bondage seruice whatsoeuer labour endeuour employ seruice yet bound v desert sith cannot owe v thing againe therefore hee proposeth similitude seruaunte hath passed ouer whole daye diligent painefull labour returning home euening continueth labour vntill hee hath done duetie according pleasure master christ doth speake hyred seruauntes serue v day olde bondman whose estate condition lyfe suche get nothing themselues giuen master theyr labour study endeuour euen vnto bloud christ teacheth boūd tyed god lesse bond seruice whereby gathereth hee way bound vnto v argument lesse greater mortall man hath suche power graunted ouer man hee may driue night day continuall obedience yet craue meanes mutuall recompence debter much shall lawfull god require dueties lyfe farre power reach yet shall owe v nothing therfore see condemned wicked arrogancy feigne themselues deserue thing god handes binde man would willinglye call▪ god accounte vvhereof imagination merites preuailed almoste age saying christe noted yeelde nothing god free wyll subiect power condition whatsoeuer v due two thing noted sentēce lyfe end race wholy bound god man employ part seruice god lawfull couenaunt liue idlelye reste time many seruice tenne yeares would gladly sette free followeth touched euen nowe god bound workes paye v rewarde therefore let euery man remember therefore created hee labour shoulde exercise himselfe dilygently office calling certeine time death selfe hee shoulde lesse dye lyue god respect merite knot stayeth hindreth many must beloused scripture oft promising reward work seemeth attribute merit thē answer easie yt reward due debt otherwise promised thē meere good wil god far deceiued cople reward wt desert mutual relatiō together god moued giue rewardes dignitie workes free mercie graunt couenaunt law god bound vnto menne perfectly perfourmed required band voluntary remaineth sure man demaund nothing god deserued thing therefore arrogancy flesh falleth downe man fulfill lawe yet bestow nothing god rendreth endebted sense calleth v vnprofitable seruaunts god receyueth v nothing due onely gathereth due lawfull fruites souereine lordship therefore two thinges noted god naturally oweth v nothing neither doe workes deserue merite worth hayre couenaunt lawe workes haue rewarde promised dignitie god might bee free debter vnthankfulnes borne man shal vnder pretence proudly lyft vp himselfe lyberally god doth deale v much maketh v bound vnto farre giuing v lybertie lyfte vp selues vaine confidence oft therefore see remember worde merit let v know abundance goodnes god towards v hath v wholly debt doth yet descend make couenaunt v vvherfore deuice sophisters much detestable dare bold frame merit worthily deseruing word merit selfe prophane straung rule pietie farre worse make men dronke diuelish pride could deserue thing worthines 10 vve haue done duety doe haue brought nothing owne haue onely doone workes due law christ speaketh perfect obseruation law found perfectest yet farre ryghteousnesse law requireth question entreated whether iustified workes whether obseruation law deserueth reward god latter denyed god hath v bound himselfe whatsoeuer proceede v accounteth owne right though true reward due respect desert obseruation law yet shall follow thereof man shall iustified desert workes wee fall obedience onely maymed part doth exactly aunswere iudgment god matth mark luke 18 1 spake also parable vnto ende ought alwayes pray wa • • aint 2 saying iudge certeine citie feared god neither reuerenced man 3 widow citie whiche came vnto saying doe iustice agaynst myne aduersary 4 • e would time afterward said himselfe though feare god reuerence man 5 yet widowe troubleth wil right least last make weary 6 lord saide heare vnrighteous iudge saith▪ 7 shal god auenge elect crye day night vnto yea though hee suffer▪ longe 8 tell hee aduenge quickely sonne man commeth shal find faith earth vvee know rare hard vertue dilygence prayer infidelytie bewrayeth selfe except graunt firste requestes presently togeather exercise caste away also hope notable tryall fayth manne receiue desire hee yet distrust yet cast away hys hope vvherfore christe dooth without cause commende perseueraunce prayer disciple also though vseth hard similytude shew yet apt whyle hee teacheth disciple earnestly attend vppon god father vntyll obtaine length force otherwise seemeth giue wyllingly god ouercome prayer doth hardly yeelde mercy dooth presently testifie indeede hee giueth eare prayer christ proposeth vnto v parable widow obtayned would vnrighteous cruell iudge beecause ceased sollicite cause dayly summe god dooth helpe presently would called vppon praiers though pray vnto miserable despised yet faint continuall course praying hee length looke vppon helpe theyr neces sities compareth equal togeather great difference beetweene wicked cruell manne god bendeth himselfe mercye christ would teach faithful feare least shoulde daily prayer entreate father mercy theyr importunitie compell men giuen crueltie wicked cruel iudge could beare suite widow therefore prayer faythful without fruit continual therefore wax weary stay wee haue prayed zeale prayer waxeth cold god seemeth dease yet let v account shal certeinely receiue profit though dooth yet appeare perswasion let v striue impatience longer delay may hinder course praier 7 shall god auenge elect iudge christ describeth v altogeather without mercy one hardned himselfe sight god hauing caste shame care opened eye length misery widow doubted faythfull shall feele least commodity cease instant god • noted christ applieth similitude purpose maketh god lyke wicked vnkinde iudge noteth farre diuerse cause differreth faithfull one delaieth long season doth indeede reach hand presentlye vnto witte long suffering vvherfore god wincketh iniuries longer would let v know hee doth fatherly wisdome might exercise v patience delaying punishment time setting sinnes free euer promiseth god aduenge quicklye ought referred prouidence rash hastie commeth tyme enough helpe flesh imagineth lawfull enter counsell wee know helpe ready hand neede requireth slacketh space moment ready season yet demaunded christ instruct disciple pray vengeaunce otherwhere teacheth disciple blesse pray persecutours aunswere christe speaketh heere vengeaunce hee derogateth nothinge doctrine god saieth auenger faythfull hee would giue raynes lybertie affection fleshe myght perswade theyr saluation deare pretious vnto also meanes byddeth trust defence without hatred free cleare wicked desire reuenge right ordred motion spirit craue helpe god prayer shall holy lawfull shall heard god himselfe nothing hard caste wicked affection lord required would direct gouerne heartes spirit may conceaue pure right praiers shall come passe may rightly call vpon god auenger praid vnto wil aunswere v 8 vvhen sonne manne commeth christe sentence declareth meruaile menne doe consume away theyr euylles witte neglect true remedie meete offence wee dayly conceaue vyle confounding thinges vnfaythfulnesse cruelty deceites fraudes violence regarde equitie shamelesnesse doe abound euery oppressed poore doe sigh innocentes proudly despitefully vexed yet god seemeth sleepe mean season heauen hereof commeth passe flesh imagineth blynd gouernment fortune christ declareth menne iustice lefte destitute heauenlye helpe confidence whereof neyther know wyll repose selues meete bee holpe god grudging inwardly haue regard prouidence christe dooth expresly foretell vnbeleeuers euery ascention heauen vnto hys returne agayne wordes declaringe redeemer shoulde appeare speedilye menne shoulde feele wante beecause manne almoste woulde looke haue regarde would god effecte prophesie euident experience teacheth though worlde bee ouerwhelmed oppressed great heape euyls yet scarse founde litle sparke faith fewe others doe take worde fayth integritie former sense dooth better agree text matth mark luke 18 9 hee spake also parable vnto certeine trusted themselues iust despised others 10 two menne w • nte vppe temple praye one pharisee publycan 11 pharisee stoode prayed thus selfe god thanke thee men extortioner vniust adulterer euen publican 12 fast twise weeke giue tyeth al euer possesse 13 publican standing farre woulde lyft vp much eye heauen smote brest saying god mercifull vnto mee sinner 14 tell man departed house iustified rather euerye manne exalteth himselfe shalbe brought low hee humbleth himselfe shalbe exalted christ giueth commaundement vertue necessary true prayer faythfull come presence god except doe humbly simply submitte themselues deadly disease arrogancy yet throughly fastened setled bone marow v scarce driuen away rooted remedy woonder men deceiued dare set vp themselues agaynst god boaste theyr merites though ambition bewitcheth v amongst men yet wee come god becommeth v forget vaine confidence euery man thinketh hath humbled himselfe sufficiently onely hypocrisie hath prayd forgiuenesse hereby learne necessary admonition lord furthermore christ reproueth two vice purposed condemne wicked trust selues pride condemning brethrē spring one whosoeuer deceiueth vaine confidence cannot shuld lift vp aboue brother neither meruaile hee despise equal pride lifteth vp himselfe god whosoeuer puft vp trust purposely maketh battell god reconciled v onelye denying selues without al hope owne power vertue righteousnes repose selues onely mercy 10 two men christ compareth two men togeather pretend exercise religion praying yet two seeme much vnlike pharisee hauing outward holynes comming god commendeth lyfe commeth offer sacrifice prayse owne right publycan man reiected knoweth himselfe vnworthy come god doth insin • ate himselfe fearefully confessing owne vnworthynes prayer christ reiecting pharisee saith praiers publican acceptable god agayn also noted two cause pharise reiected wit trusting righteousnes extold himsefe condemning others yet reprehended lyfted vp himselfe force free trusted reconciled god desert work giuing thankes vseth testifieth hee glorieth owne strength obtaine righteousnes himselfe deserue thing owne industrie rather ascrybeth grace god righteous though giuing thāks god confesseth good work soeuer hath meere benefit god yet putteth trust workes preferreth himselfe others prayer reiected whereby wee gather menne rightly perfectly humbled though account canne nothing themselues except also distrusting merites theyr workes doe learne place theyr saluation free goodnes god theyr whole trust confidence grounded notable place seemeth sufficient take manne glory good workes gyftes holy ghost interprete wee iustified freely god found righteousnes v brought christ goeth onely assigninge power well grace spirit taketh v truste workes pharisee therefore reproued challengeth himselfe proper god trusteth owne merites would haue god mercifull vnto hadde deserued therefore let v knowe though manne ascribe prayse good workes god yet hee imagine righteousnes cause saluation trusteth condemned peruerse arrogancye note reproued vaine ambition wherein men otherwise guiltie selues glory amongst men secrete hypocrisie said setter forth owne prayses praide secretly himselfe though hee sette forth owne righteousnes lowd voice yet inward pride abhominable god glorying two thinges first freeth himselfe common guyltinesse menne setteth foorth owne prayses hee sayeth hee one common sorte free sinnes reigne euery worlde hee boasteth hee fasted twise euery weeke gaue tythes hys goodes much hee shoulde haue sayde hee perfourmed law required euen monkes poperie doe preache workes supererogation though smal thing fulfil law god though euery man measure vertues god hathe bestowed vppon bound giue thankes authour godly meditation consider howe much euery manne hath receiued least ouerwhelme blessing god vnthankfulnesse yet two thing obserued least lifted vp confidēce satisfied god become insolent despising brother pharisie sinneth falsly chalenging righteousnesse himselfe leaueth nothing mercy god despiseth others respecte himselfe christ woulde haue reproued thankes giuinge bene polluted two sinnes proude hypocrite winking owne sinnes opposed imagination sound perfect righteousnesse iudgement god necessary hee shoulde fall wicked sacrilegious boldnesse hope godly long labour vnder infirmitie flesh acknowledge good thing haue flee mercy god set saluation obtaining forgiuenesse demaunded howe haue great holinesse blinded wicked pride great perfection cannot come way spirite god assured doth raigne hypocrite answer trusted outwarde shew secreat inward vncleannes heart shuld come account vvherfore thogh full within wicked concupiscence yet pretēdeth innocency carelesly iudgeth outward shew lord reproueth vanitie falsly chalengeth himselfe yet noted man free rapine vnrighteousnesse lust vice except gouerned spirite god vseth thys woorde sabboth place ofte time otherwhere weeke god doeth commaunde lawe seruants shuld fast euery weeke wherefore fasting tenthes voluntary exercise without prescript commaundement law 13 publicane standing farre christ deliuereth generall rule necessary looke ground oft pray onely noteth signes humilitie commendeth disciple humilitie placed spare owne sinnes condemning themselues doe preuent iudgements god doe simply confesse owne guiltinesse might reconciled god hether belongeth shame alwaies companion repentance lorde certainly doeth especially stande vppon publicane earnestly acknowledging owne misery wretched estate onely fleeth mercy god though sinner yet obtaining free forgiuenesse hopeth god wil become fauorable vnto sum might obtain fauor confesseth himselfe vnwoorthy certainly sith forgiuenesse sinnes doeth onely reconcile v god necessary shoulde beginne desire haue prayer acceptable furrher confessed himselfe guiltie conuicte yet desireth pardoned banisheth himselfe al confidence work purpose christ shew god would entreated fearfully flie onely mercy 14 man departed house iustified improper comparison iustified christ onely preferreth publicane degree meaneth acceptable god pharisie altogither reiected place doeth teach v euidently worde iustified doeth properly signifie namely stand god righteous neither publicane therefore sayd iustified sodainly gotten newe qualitie guiltines pardoned sinnes abolished obtained fauour whereof foloweth righteousnesse consisteth forgiuenesse sinnes therefore wicked confidence defiled polluted vertues pharisie life laudable world accounted god publicane holpe merites desert workes obtained righteousnesse onely praying forgiuenesse trusted thing mercy god seemeth absurde menne brought order sith sainctes much holyer publican answear much soeuer man hath profited worship god true holinesse yet consider much yet wanteth perfection cānot otherwise pray rightly except begin confessiō guiltines thogh le yet generally faultie vvherfore douted christ prescribeth law al mē haue said god pleased v distrusting workes seeke reconciled frely grace papist enforced part graunt presently corrupt doctrine wicked comment graunt haue neede forgiuenesse man perfecte first make miserable men dronken vaine hope partiall righteousnesse call adde satisfaction whereby shuld wipe away guiltinesse ought onely stay faith wee accepted god haue deserued imputeth sinnes mathewe marke luke 17 11 went ierusalem passed mids samaria galile 12 • hee entred certaine towne met 10 mē leper stode far 13 lift vp voyces sayde iesus maister haue mercy v 14 saw sayd vnto go shewe selues vnto priestes came passe went cleansed 15 one saw healed turned backe loude voice praised god 16 fel downe face feete gaue thankes samaritane 17 iesus answeared said ten cleansed nine 18 none found returned giue god praise saue straunger 19 sayde vnto arise goe thy way thy • aith hath made thee whole 20 hee demaunded pharis • e kingdom god come answeared sayde kingdome god commeth obseruation 21 neither shal men say loe loe beholde kingdome god among mathew eight chapter two euangelists declared christe healed one leper luke reporteth like myracle shewed healing 10 leper purpose hystory described vile incredible vnthankfulnesse iewish nation least seeme wonder man many benefites christ suppressed many myracles buried circumstance also added infameth offence lorde healed nine iewes one gaue thankes disease might forgotten escape away stealth one samaritan professeth oweth christ therfore one part shewed diuine power christ againe wickednesse iewes reprooued whereby came passe almost honour giuen notable myracle 13 iesus master appeareth al faith craue aid christ giue title master also may gathered ready obedience spake frō heart fainedly although yet sawe filthy scabbe vpon flesh yet assone commanded shew themselues priest obey without delay adde also wold neuer haue gone priest perswasion faith haue bene scorne offer themselues iudges leprosie witnesse clensing promise christ bene forcible present beholding disease cary visible leprosie flesh yet trusting worde christe dout professe themselues cleane therefore cannot denied sede faith planted heart thogh certaine regenerate spirit adoption yet absurditie helde beginning pietie much feared least befall vnto v sparkes faith shining v extinguished▪ thogh liuely faith neuer dieth hath rote fastned spirit regeneratiō yet see otherwhere many haue conceiued faith time doth presently vanish away disease common necessitie enforceth v therby mind caried seke god yea lord himselfe secrete instincte spirite solliciteth v thereto haue obtained desire howe doeth vnthankfull forgetfulnesse swallowe vp sense feeling pietie want hunger engendereth faith fulnesse killeth 14 go shew selues priest answer much shuld haue said wer clensed know iudgemēt leprosie law cōmāded priest shuld discerne cleane frō vncleane christ leaueth thē right without diminishing maketh witness allowers myracle therefore sayd men esteemed holily reuerently christe yet diseased onely word presently conceiue hope health papist doe fondly gather auricular confession hence leprous menne sent graunt christe priest vomite sinnes eares rather sent offer sacrifice according commaundement law neither sent purge themselues popish confession saying bringeth cleannesse nowe cleane shoulde shewe themselues priestes double fooles considering silthy blot infamie cast vpon confession haue behaued themselues well al multitude haue gone priestes tenth part onely returneth christe rest wickedly alienated away cannot pretende title confession shalbe lawfull returne againe fruite vpon none returned priest giue glory god trifle let passe vnderstand end mention made priestes came passe went heere appeared diuine power christe wordes heere also instruction giuen howe much obedience faith shoulde please god heereof came sodaine health beinge good hope doubted take iourney christ commaundement vanishing faith wanting liuely roote onely brought herbe yet adorned god wonderfull effecte howe much excellent reward remaineth faith setled sincerely perfectly god thoughe health body profited 9 leper saluation • leeting fraile faith onely obtained temporall gifte yet vnder figure shewed v effectuall true faith shalbe 15 one vncertaine whether returned midste iourney luke wordes seeme signifie yet semeth probable came giue thanks vntill heard iudgement priestes behoued restored priest common societie neither lawfull neglectinge commaundement christ defraude temple god sacrifice except coniecture shall rather like assoone sawe himselfe cleansed desired testimonie priestes beinge caried holy godly zeale came authour hee might begin sacrifice thankesgiuing christes wordes vpbraiding whole nation doeth odiously compare one stranger many iewes common thing amongst deuoure benefites god without sense godlinesse hereof commeth passe many notable myracles christe almost name amongest yet let v know generally condemned complaint except become thankefull god benefites 19 thy faith hath saued thee interpreaters restraine worde sauing cleansing flesh sith christ commendeth liuely faith samaritane may demaunded howe nine saued generally like health thus therefore noted christe heere iudged otherwise gifte god prophane men doe namely comfortable token pledge loue father nine leaper healed wickedly blotte grace god vnthankfulnesse hindereth polluteth health selfe take profite ought therefore faith sanctifieth giftes god may pure v ioyned lawful vse may saluation short christ declareth worde vse benefites god rightly vvherby gather eternall saluation soule ioyned togither temporall gift samaritane saued faith certainly healed leaprousie common rest accepted number child god receiued token fatherly loue hand 20 demaunded pharisies question vndoubtedly moued scorne christ spoken daily kingdome god hand chaunge outward state amongest iewes wicked malitious menne thought plausible coulour vexe trouble therfore speakein vain trifle kingdom god doe aske iestingly length kingdome shall come yet shall thinke rather asked question grosse ignorāce scorne doe striue kingdom god commeth christ iudgement neglecting dogges applieth answeare disciple prouoked wicked tooke thereby occasion teach malice laughed scrone lorde truth defended cauils sheweth selfe christ vseth word obseruation great glory shuld deny kingdome god come loftily pomp declareth much deceiued seeke kingdome god whiche carnall earthly fleshly eye nothing else inwarde spirituall renewing soule teacheth peruersly nature kingdome looke hither might obserue visible note shoulde haue sayde restitution churche god hath promised must sought inwardly giuing electe heauenly newnesse life setteth vp kingdome doeth ouerthwartly reprooue slouthfulnesse pharisies aspire nothing whiche earthly transitorie yet noted christ spake beginning kingdom god vsuall originall earth vvhy doe rather lift vp eye heauen might learne came god excelleth man reason furthermore myracles ioyned doctrine ought touche depelier least waken sleeping much securitie might giue glory god certainly god dealeth vnwonted meanes doeth much euidently shew power hande yet cause nazarites malitiously drew veile ouer eye therefore see simple ignorance hurt menne willingly tooke offence themselues least follow whether god calleth behoueth v rather reason cōtrary part humane meanes doe want power god doeth euidently shewe selfe might haue whole praise himselfe 55 carpenter sonne vve know wōderful counsel god christ kept priuate life vntil 30 yeres old hereof nazarites wickedly vniustly tooke offence ought rather reuerently embrace one sodainly falne heauen see god working christ thereof sette purpose turne eye ioseph marie kinsfolkes whose estate meane base vaile drawne betweene manifest light vve haue sayd kinsfolkes called brother maner hebrewes vvherefore heluidius imagined fondly marie moe sonnes mention made oft brother christ 57 prophet without honour haue expounded sentence largely 4 chap iohn may generall prouerbe excel excellent gift reprehended saying wont spokē whole nation christ doth properly apply countrey menne galilean neuer lesse estemed place borne vvherfore reproueth worthily ought haue bene first haue embraced grace matter agree wel way shutte vp christ wickednesse owne citizen worke many myracles amongst giuē tast willingly amase themselues least vnderstand thing therefore augustine doth aptly compare faith open mouth vessel sayth infidelitie like couer wherwith vessel couered lest shuld receiue liquor powred god truely matter euen lorde seeth receiue power length withdraweth yet meane complaine 〈◊〉 want helpe incredulitie driueth remoueth farre v marke sayinge christe coulde amplifieth offence whome goodnesse staid certainly vnbeleuers much lieth holde backe hand god obstinacie god ouercome inferiour permit shewe power▪ yet noted marke addeth notwithstanding sicke folke healed hereby gather goodnesse christ striue malice might goe beyond hinderance vve doe finde god daily though necessarily iustly withholdeth power way v open yet see making himselfe way place impassable ceaseth v good wonderfull contention doe meanes endeuour ouerwhelme grace god least come vnto v yet conquerour breaketh extreme necessity whereinto cast especially require helpe god redemer present partly witnessed cry iohn partly himselfe testifieth owne office enforced acknowledge diuine power yet falling owne deuises chaunge personne truely world wicked vnthankfulnesse vseth extinguish grace god offred thē respect herode himselfe touched little conceiued opinion iohn raised ioy euill conscience doe quake fearefully doe bende euery blast easily conceiueth feared god often scourgeth vngodly blind terrours though hardē themselues purpose neither vexed yet obtaine rest inwarde slaughterman sharply herode bolder might freelier reprochefull iniurious quiet softe manne apt make warre also probable coniecture herodias rather giuen mariage vncle philippe great vncle graundfathers brother beinge nowe weake worne olde manne herode antipas whome mention heere made philippe brother one mother firste borne marthaca thirde wife herode greate borne cleopatra nowe retourne euangelistes say iohn cast bandes hadde freely reprooued wickednesse herode cruelty tyrant would beare nowe hainousnesse offence odious infamous enough selfe onely fetche mannes wife lawfull bedde kept owne house iniury germane brother vvhen iohn freely reprooued herode feared vaine least sedition raised sodenly lust suffer amende sinne promiseth himselfe safe quiet liberty casting prophet god bandes ignorance hystorie caused many thrust vaine disputation whether lawfull take wife first maried brother though naturall shame abhorreth suche mariage yet iohn rather condemneth taking away husband rather incest herode force deceite hadde robbed brother lawfull wife otherwise lesse lawfull take neece wife deade brother wydowhoode doubted hainous offence spoken euery others reproued herode euill speaches absence onely iohn commeth presence reproueth freely face might might meanes brought repentaunce vvhereby learne constant courage behooueth child god furnished haue doe prince hypocrisie seruile flattery raigneth almoste courtes eares prince customed pleasant speaches abide wordes shal sharply reproue sinnes sinne vile prophet god might dissemble iohn cō meth though neither haue reward thankes yet least neglect duety doubteth incurre displeasure tyrant especially knewe caught snare harlot could scarce remoued purpose 5 vvhen would haue put death semeth difference mat markes wordes first sayth herode desirous cruel murther staid fear people chargeth herodias cruelty āswer easy herode woulde beginning haue slaine holy man except greater perswasion compelled reuerenced truely reuerend feare stared raging cruelly prophet god herodias pricking daily forward caused shake feare god frō caried foorth rage fury desired holy man dead yet staied new let feared moouing people markes wordes noted herodias sayeth hee laide waite namely herode forward willing murder tried either circumuent synister deuices worke secreat destruction vpon holy mā first opinion pleaseth best sought entrap minde husband subtlety vain long herodes cōscience withstode shee coulde destroy holy man followed feare least tumulte shoulde arise hainous crueltie death marke toucheth staid herode giuing present place harlot request herodias desired iohn bene secreatly put death assoone cast prison herode reuerenced holy man woulde willingly haue obeied counsel also feare mentioned feare conceiued estimation feare gette authoritie credite thoughe wee esteeme vnworthy honour feare willing reuerence herode durst despise perswaded holy manne faithfull minister god worthy noted though iohn hadde experience profitable many way credite tetrarche yet feared displease could otherwise keepe fauor winking treacherously notorious infamous wickednesse might haue said regarded priuate commodity neither respect common profite certaine sought nothing ambitiously herode obedient holy counsel whiche appertained lawfull administration kingdome sawe kinde recompence lawfull might betraying truthe gette shewes liking chuseth frende rather make ennemie flattery silence nourishe sinne enforced seuerely reprehend iohn therefore example prescribeth certaine rule godly teacher dissemble winke vice prince though price buy fauour profitable common estate spirit god doeth shew vnto v herode glasse befalleth oft time worship god sincerely yet ready poynt obey cōmandemēts may haue liberty graunted release whē straightly dealt become obstinate casting yoake also mad therefore cause please themselues yelde obedience many good counsel vntil haue learned yeld themselues wholely god 6 vvhen herodes birthe day kepte euangelistes doe nowe begin declare fraude herodias brought destruction iohn passe length long time practised occasion giuen solemne 〈◊〉 kept herode celebrated birth day 〈…〉 scarcely great bankets besides luxury pride 〈…〉 wickedness also drawe many mischiefes euil selfe make rich banket readinesse mannes witte wantonnes • e raines lette louse doe easily runne course ancient custome cannot disallowed solemnizing birth day euery yere day oft commeth admonisheth euery one v giue thākes god brought life hath blessing passed ouer many yeares remember yll vnprofitably hath suffered time pearish graunted god lastly shoulde commend himselfe rest life protection god nothing pure worlde corrupt sinnes part prophaneth filthy corruption birthe day ought holy almoste sumptuous banket free dissolute wantonnesse first much drunke doore opened filthy vnmodest speaches lastly temperance holden mooued holy iob sonnes banketting togither course offer sacrifice thought men could neuer moderate themselues wel companion inuite eache mery offence grow many wayes came passe herode meaning entertaine guest sumptuously suffred wife daughter dāce heereby also appeareth discipline court though many gaue themselues liberty dance yet vile note whorish wantonnes damsel mariageable dance filthy herodias framed daughter salome maners lest shuld shame folowed namely vngodly slaughter godly prophet heat wine herode flamed forgetting grauity wisedom promised would giue dauncing damsell euen one halfe kingdome truely shamefull example drunken king doeth abide looke vpon fauourable eye shameful shew housholde also promiseth great reward vvherfore let v learne carefully resist deuil least entrap v snare mar 24 went foorth sayd mother maruaile herodias make great account death iohn many coniecture kindled desire reuēge voyd reason feare diuorcement rather troubled vexed parte whoremaster begin loath ashamed lust hoped offence haue herode bound vnto couenaunt adulterous bedde confirmed sealed bloud prophet sacrifice therefore might rule hereafter without care would haue put death found alone enemy vvhereby also taught miserable griefe alwayes tormenteth euill conscience iohn kepte bandes imperious cruell womanne myght haue forbidden people speaking comminge yet resteth vexed care feare vntyll prophet shuld made away also much auaileth shewing forth efficacie woorde god voyce holy manne though shutte vppe prison doeth vexe minde king wife grieuous torment 26 king sorie religion vanished heart sayd foreseeth odious crime wold feareth infamie also danger hereof commeth passe repē teth lightnesse yet dare deny dauncer least accounted inconstant though worse retracte rashly fondly promised constant detestable offence respecte perfecte vanitie king haue woorde broken giuen presently commaundeth prophet slaine gather herode supped night macherontis tower wherein iosephus sayeth iohn imprisoned worth labour note euangelists doe say othe guest present whereof gather sworne hundred time man present witnesse yet would haue perfourmed promisse therefore religion conscience bounde herode meere ambition caried headlong accounted honestie perfourme faith giuen commeth passe wicked men neglecte duety haue respecte god bent euill spoken men furthermore onely religion othe ben regarded herode shame men yet sinned grieuously perfourming foolishly promised broken othe first vnaduised rashnesse swearing confirmeth promisse doubtfull matter othe appeared hee coulde sette free faith giuen hee shoulde plunge himselfe hainous offence lawfull wrap vp holy name offence god chiefe vngodly murther question moued priuate losse discredite lette swoare rashly beare punishment foolishnesse must taken heede man hath taken name god vaine least pretence abused committing offence commit double sacriledge heereof foloweth monkish vowes manifest wickednesse adioyned doe binde conscience thē magicall exorcismes god wil haue sacred name enforced confirmation sinne yet place doth teach v take heede man vnaduisedly promisse thing ioyne obstinacie lightnesse 28 gaue maide also encreaseth crueltie offence holy man head death brought forth scorned lord doth somtimes submit child pride wicked vntil wil shew length bloud child pretious eye herodias ioyeth shee hath obtained desire cruelly triūpheth ouer reprouer afterwards put richesse depriued onely honour kingdom also natiue country help pore woman painfully led miserable life banishment shewed ioyful fight angel good men guestes enforced defile eye beholdinge abhominable pompe doe heereby learne sitte prince table oft entrapped many sinnes though bloudy offence defile table yet thing filled kinde wickednesse soeuer come thither behoueth thē least giuen prank baudry 29 disciple came remained also cruelty woman corpes holy man remained vnburied probable disciple performed duty body thrown forth tyrant officer though honour buriall profiteth dead yet lord would ceremonie shuld reuerenced v might witnesse vnto v last resurrection vvherefore endeuour acceptable god iohns disciple shoulde come bury maisters body testimony piety meanes professed doctrine deade man yet liued woman little child 30 apostle gathered themselues togither iesus tolde thing done taught 31 sayd vnto come ye parte wildernesse rest many cōmers goer leisure eat 32 went shippe way desart place 33 people sawe departed many knowe ranne foote thither city came thither assembled vnto 34 iesus went sawe great multitude compassion like sheepe shephearde hee began teach many thing 35 day farre spent disciple came vnto saying desart place day farre passed 36 let depart may go village town buy breade haue nothing eate 37 answeared sayde vnto giue ye eat solde vpto shall goe buy two hundreth pepy woorth breade giue eate 38 sayd vnto howe many loaues haue yee goe looke knewe sayde fiue two fish 39 commanded make sit downe company vpon greene grasse 40 sate downe rowes hundreths fifty 41 tooke
